author: By Sam Roberts
title: R. Allen Gardner, 91, Dies; Taught Sign Language to a Chimp Named Washoe
description: He and his wife and collaborator made headlines with their finding that they could communicate with a young ape using the language of the deaf.
content: Washoe was 10 months old when her foster parents began teaching her to talk, and five months later they were already trumpeting her success. Not only had she learned words; she could also string them together, creating expressions like “water birds” when she saw a pair of swans and “open flower” to gain admittance to a garden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: London Police, Under Fire on Everard Murder, Respond With Safety Tips
description: The guidance after the sentencing of Wayne Couzens, who abused his power as a police officer to falsely arrest and murder Sarah Everard, 33, provoked widespread criticism and mockery.
content: LONDON — Challenging officers by asking them “searching questions.” Flagging down a bus, or running into a house. Asking for help from bystanders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Global Natural Gas Crunch Roils Consumers and Industry
description: Rising demand for the fuel is sending electricity bills soaring and forcing factories to shut down.
content: Much of the world is suddenly worried about running short of natural gas, and the impact is being felt in surging utility bills, shuttered factories and a rising desperation as winter approaches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: If You’re Feeling ‘Fatalistic’ About Our Dystopia, You’re Not Alone
description: It’s hard to stay mobilized after five years of unceasing crises.
content: This Saturday, there will be demonstrations across the country to protest Texas’ crowdsourced abortion ban and the Supreme Court’s refusal to enjoin it. It could be a broad mobilization. Rachel O’Leary Carmona, executive director of the Women’s March, part of the coalition organizing the protests, told me there are 650 marches planned nationwide. I’ll be happily surprised, however, if any of the events are very large. Organizers have applied for a permit for 10,000 people in Washington. That’s about 10 percent of the people who showed up there for the third Women’s March in 2019.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: What to Know About California’s Free School Lunch Program
description: California recently became the first state to offer free breakfast and lunch to all schoolchildren.
content: When classrooms went dark last year as the coronavirus pandemic took hold, many school kitchens stayed open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: N.W.S.L., Reeling in Scandal, Cancels a Weekend of Games
description: Under pressure for its handling of abuse accusations, the top U.S. women’s soccer league called off five games and announced its commissioner had resigned.
content: By the time hundreds of professional women’s soccer players gathered on a videoconference Thursday night, they had all had enough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Jon Caramanica, Isabelia Herrera and Giovanni Russonello
title: Kane Brown and H.E.R.’s Genre-Melting Duet, and 11 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by John Mellencamp and Bruce Springsteen, Ashnikko, Susana Baca and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Gorman
title: The Beet Grows On
description: A pandemic garden didn’t really prepare me for “semi-retirement,” but …
content: As my first gardening season in many years draws to a close, I am confronting the weighty question of when to harvest my beet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sullivan
title: Private Jet Market Grapples With Surge in Get-Me-Away Demand
description: Waits for charter flights are longer, and costs higher, as many more of the rich seek to avoid crowded planes and airports.
content: Even people who can normally afford to charter a private jet at a moment’s notice are being forced to be patient and, often, pay more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland, Daniel Axelrod and Jutharat Pinyodoonyachet
title: Who Wouldn’t Want a $500 Million Theme Park in Their Town?
description: When Legoland arrived in Goshen, N.Y., it divided residents into first-time environmental activists or business boosters. Now that the park is open, can neighbors piece together a way to move ahead?
content: You live in a small town where people cherish their open space. Neighbors drop in without calling ahead, and come together in a townwide $5 charity challenge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosalie R. Radomsky
title: Side By Side With a Real Trooper
description: Liz Wessel’s dog, Trooper, caught Matt Ross’s eye on Hinge, and when the pandemic hit they gave up their New York apartment, and hit the road.
content: Elizabeth Catherine Wessel is definitely a love-me-love-my-dog person. So she couldn’t be happier when Trooper upstaged her in February 2017 after Matthew Stephen Ross spotted their photo on the dating app Hinge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Louise Snyder
title: ‘I Don’t Want to Hit My Children. I Don’t Want to Hit Anybody.’
description: Can a hotline for perpetrators help stop domestic violence?
content: When I was a young teenager, I was uncontrollable, rebellious. My father believed in corporal punishment, sanctioned by the evangelical church. My mother, who was Jewish, died of cancer when I was 8, and I believe my father’s response to his grief was to double down on his faith: to interpret the Bible literally, to make himself the ultimate authority in our home and to try to create the world he wanted through sheer force. He cobbled together a new family — stepmother, stepsiblings and then two more children from the new marriage. Overwhelmed with change and with my own grief, I defied his every edict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: A Battle of the Bubbles: War Comes to the Prosecco Hills
description: A Croatian wine, Prosek, seeks an official designation, and Prosecco makers are up in arms. But they also can’t agree on what, exactly, should be called Prosecco.
content: VALDOBBIADENE, ITALY — Small pickup trucks carrying mounds of green grapes wound through Prosecco Road. Workers harvesting in the terraced vineyards squinted in the sun. Tipsy tourists stopped in for tastings. Couples clinked glasses in the town’s quaint Prosecco bars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno
title: Takao Saito, 84, Dies; Created a Japanese Comic Book Superstar
description: Over a half-century and in more than 200 collected volumes, his manga tales of Golgo 13, a globe-trotting assassin, steered Japanese comics toward adults.
content: TOKYO — Takao Saito, who created “Golgo 13,” a manga comic book series that has sold in staggering numbers over a half-century, making its assassin-for-hire antihero one of Japan’s most recognizable characters and the world of Japanese comics a darker, more adult place, died here on Sept 24. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kimberlé Crenshaw
title: How R. Kelly Got Away With It
description: The singer’s abuse of Black women and girls was hiding in plain sight.
content: R. Kelly believed he could lie about his sexual predation and bury the allegations against him with an endless supply of cash, distractions and legal maneuvering. For more than two decades, he was absolutely right. But this week, his victims finally found justice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: After 100 Years, a Royal Wedding in Russia Evokes Days of the Czars
description: For the groom, a Romanov and descendant of the imperial throne, and his Italian bride, the wedding represents the pinnacle of their attempts to re-establish a monarchic presence in Russia’s public life.
content: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — Under the watch of a ceremonial honor guard, the bride walked slowly down the aisle as a flock of young attendants held her 23-foot train aloft. The groom, clad in black coattails, stood expectantly under the golden dome of St. Isaac’s Cathedral as his mother watched from a thronelike marble enclosure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Judge Rebukes Mounties’ Handling of Fairy Creek Logging Protest
description: The enforcement methods of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police led a court to deny a logging company’s request to extend an injunction.
content: This week, the Supreme Court of British Columbia refused to extend an injunction against old growth forest protests in and around Fairy Creek on Vancouver Island. But the rejection had nothing to do with logging or the actions of the protesters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebekah Peppler
title: It’s the Season for Cider. Here’s How to Drink It.
description: Added to cocktails, sipped on its own or even turned into a syrup, this drink with a long history is anything but simple.
content: Autumn is here and, despite the aggressive push for pumpkin spice, it’s unequivocally apple — and cider — season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Justice Kavanaugh tests positive for the virus.
description: The Supreme Court justice is fully vaccinated, a court spokeswoman said, and is not showing symptoms.
content: Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh has tested positive for the coronavirus, a Supreme Court spokeswoman said on Friday. She said the justice had been fully vaccinated since January and that he was not showing symptoms of the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Review: The Costume Dramas of New York City Ballet
description: The Fall Fashion Gala returned with new works by Sidra Bell and Andrea Miller that felt like fast fashion: flimsy.
content: It’s been a long 18 months spent languishing in soft clothes, but, finally, fashion is making a comeback on the streets of New York City. It also returned to the stage of New York City Ballet. On Thursday, the company resurrected its Fall Fashion Gala at Lincoln Center with two new ballets dressed up in designer clothing from head — or, in once instance, a headpiece veering into lampshade territory — to pointe shoe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Schaverien
title: The Strange Allure of Pool-Cleaning Videos
description: Clips of swimming pools being cleaned have racked up millions of views on TikTok. Researchers have some ideas as to why.
content: Some TikTok creators have become successful on the video platform by dancing, singing or performing everyday tasks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: Space Force Uniforms Meant to Capture the Vastness of Space
description: Any similarities to Star Trek are a coincidence.
content: When President Donald J. Trump signed the act establishing the United States Space Force in 2019, he made not only a sixth branch of the military but also a design challenge for the ages. The visual identity for a new armed service would have to be created from scratch, for the first time since the Air Force became independent from the Army in 1947.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Tommy Kirk, Young Star of ‘Old Yeller,’ Is Dead at 79
description: For a time, he was a Disney regular, seen in movies like “Swiss Family Robinson” and “The Shaggy Dog.” But his career derailed.
content: Tommy Kirk, who was a busy star in the Disney universe as a child and young man, appearing in “Old Yeller,” “The Shaggy Dog,” “Swiss Family Robinson” and other movies in the late 1950s and early ’60s, but whose career was derailed when his homosexuality became too widely known and when drugs and alcohol got the better of him, died on Tuesday at his home in Las Vegas. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Ann Dowd Sails Around New York Harbor
description: The Emmy-winning actress stars in an indie film, “Mass,” which opens this week.
content: The actress Ann Dowd stood straight-backed at the helm, hands gripping the wheel, eyes fixed on the green-gray-blue river spread before her like a rumpled blanket. The Statue of Liberty beckoned just beyond.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: ‘We’ve Become Too Complicated’: Where Eric Adams Thinks Democrats Went Wrong
description: New York’s likely next mayor shares his vision for public safety, housing and “kitchen table issues.”
content: In July, Eric Adams narrowly won the Democratic nomination for mayor of New York, making him the odds-on favorite to win in November. And he won the nomination by running directly against the verities of today’s progressives: asserting that the police are the answer, not the problem; that “defund the police” misjudged what communities of color actually want; that Democrats had lost touch with the multiracial working-class voters they claim to represent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura McKowen
title: How I Knew I Needed to Quit Instagram
description: Just like with alcohol, social media left me feeling anxious and removed from myself.
content: This summer, I relapsed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Biden’s Slide With Key Voters: Momentary Blip or Danger Sign?
description: Polls show women and other reliably Democratic voters have soured on the president’s performance, raising questions about the causes of dissatisfaction.
content: President Biden’s approval rating among key Democratic constituencies has declined considerably in recent months, eroding or even reversing decades-long patterns in public opinion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelia Herrera
title: Tirzah’s Genre-Less Pop Embraces the Beauty of Uncertainty
description: The British singer-songwriter’s new album, “Colourgrade,” is a fluid excursion through the contours of trip-hop, noise, R&B and electronic music.
content: Some pop artists amplify familiar, universal feelings: the gentle moments spent in love, the torturous pain of heartbreak. But others require us to listen with different ears. They ask us to release control, to resist the desire to fully understand music — to linger in the experience of melody, feeling and sound, even if we can’t quite grasp its meaning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis and Neal E. Boudette
title: Rivian, an Electric Vehicle Start-Up, Reveals Large Losses in its I.P.O. Filing
description: The company, which is backed by Amazon and Ford, is seeking to sell shares in one of the biggest initial public offerings of the year.
content: Rivian, an electric truck maker backed by Amazon and Ford Motor, on Friday revealed huge losses and a voracious need for cash as it headed into one of the most anticipated initial public offerings of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: House Democrats delay a crucial vote.
content: President Biden signed a short-term spending bill to fund the U.S. government until early December and avoid an imminent shutdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: U.S. and Europe Announce New Trade Cooperation, but Disputes Linger
description: A new trade and technology partnership aims to counter China, but tensions over issues like metal tariffs remain.
content: WASHINGTON — The United States and the European Union took a step this week toward a closer alliance by announcing a new partnership for trade and technology, but tensions over a variety of strategic and economic issues are still simmering in the background.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: I Know This Is Crazy, but Maybe We Should Live Under Majority Rule
description: Or at least try it.
content: There are 51 votes — the Senate Democratic caucus plus Vice President Kamala Harris — to raise the debt limit and save the United States from default.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Matt Amodio Beats James Holzhauer’s Streak on ‘Jeopardy!’
description: The Yale Ph.D. student, who is studying computer science, has won 33 games in a row, making him No. 2 on the game show’s hall of fame roster for longest streaks.
content: Two years ago, one “Jeopardy!” contestant, James Holzhauer, captured the imaginations of game-show fans who watched nightly to see his lightning-fast buzzer reflexes and risky bets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: Nearly 60 Reported Dead in Effort to Reach Canary Islands
description: As the dangerous voyage from Western Africa to the Spanish archipelago has become a more popular migrant route to Europe, the death toll has risen sharply.
content: Nearly 60 African migrants are believed to have drowned while trying to reach Spain’s Canary Islands, the latest tragedy during a year when fatalities on this ocean crossing have more than doubled from the same period in 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Riddle of Tony Soprano and Selling Marijuana on Tribal Lands: The Week in Narrated Articles
description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
content: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Georgia Arrests Former Leader Mikheil Saakashvili
description: The onetime Georgian president returned from eight years in exile to face arrest, saying he wanted to support his political party in local elections this weekend.
content: MOSCOW — Mikheil Saakashvili, a former president of Georgia and once a prominent figure in the politics of post-Soviet countries, was arrested on Friday on charges he called politically motivated after returning secretly to Georgia following eight years in exile.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tina Isaac-Goizé
title: The Parisians Are Over FOGO
description: Fear of going out? Non! New hotels, restaurants and clubs in the French capital are generating excitement, so get ready for the return of the wait list.
content: PARIS — On a recent sunny afternoon, a cluster of young women in short dresses and high boots crowded into a special elevator at Cheval Blanc, a new hotel in the La Samaritaine complex along the Seine, and were whisked up to the restaurant Le Tout-Paris. Reinvented as a Pop-inspired contemporary brasserie offering classics like sole meunière for two, it has a terrace that offers an uninterrupted view stretching from the Eiffel Tower to Notre Dame — and is the perfect setting for a selfie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: In the parallel universe that is the House of Representatives, September never ended.
description: By keeping the legislative day from ending, Speaker Nancy Pelosi avoided breaking a promise to moderates to hold a vote by month’s end.
content: It is the first day of October. The air is crisp in Washington, Halloween is near, and yes, it’s time for that same Green Day joke about September ending.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Alex Jones Loses by Default in Sandy Hook Defamation Lawsuits
description: A Texas judge ruled that Mr. Jones “failed to comply” with his obligations to produce information in two lawsuits brought by parents of children who died in the 2012 school shooting.
content: Alex Jones, the Infowars founder and conspiracy theorist who claimed that the Sandy Hook school shooting in 2012 was a hoax, has lost two defamation lawsuits filed in Texas by victims’ families because he failed to provide requested information to the court, filings show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Disney World’s 50th anniversary celebration begins, with much at stake.
description: The company hopes the 18-month extravaganza will bring hundreds of millions of dollars to it and the Orlando economy — both of which are still trying to recover from the pandemic.
content: “I don’t do business with carnival people.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Carlos Watson, the chief of Ozy Media, resigns from NPR’s board.
description: The development is latest following reports in The New York Times questioning Ozy’s business practices.
content: Ozy Media’s co-founder and chief executive, Carlos Watson, resigned from the board of NPR, the public radio organization said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal
title: India retaliates against Britain by requiring U.K. visitors to quarantine.
description: The move followed anger in India over Britain’s quarantine requirement for people who received an Indian-manufactured version of the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine.
content: India said on Friday that it would require visitors from Britain to quarantine regardless of their vaccination status — a retaliatory measure after weeks of talks to reverse a similar move by Britain appeared deadlocked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Reyes
title: Their Future Was Written on the Calendar
description: Efrain Guerrero and James Jones had an instant chemistry after meeting three years ago, though each had a different way of expressing love for each other.
content: Establishing a joint Google calendar may not be a standard marker of a flourishing romance, but for Efrain Guerrero and James Jones, it stood in just fine for a more customary expression of commitment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: Getting By With a Little Help From Her Friends
description: Jayne Allen’s debut novel, “Black Girls Must Die Exhausted,” introduces a Los Angeles reporter who is enduring more than her share of worries.
content: BLACK GIRLS MUST DIE EXHAUSTEDBy Jayne Allen
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Lipsyte
title: Joshua Ferris’s Ode to the Hapless American Everyman
description: “A Calling for Charlie Barnes,” Ferris’s new novel, is a vivid portrait of a man’s dreams and failures.
content: A CALLING FOR CHARLIE BARNESBy Joshua Ferris
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Amazon, HBO, Hulu and More in October
description: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of October’s most promising new titles.
content: (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Corkery
title: ‘Everything Going the Wrong Way’: Dollar Stores Hit a Pandemic Downturn
description: Their business model is being tested by worker burnout, pressure to raise wages, supply chain problems and growing local opposition.
content: Sandra Beadling was fed up with the 70-hour workweeks, the delivery trucks running days behind schedule, and the wear and tear on her knees from all the stooping to restock the bottom shelves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lawrence Ulrich
title: High Octane and a Stick Shift: Standout Cars as an Era Starts to End
description: Hitting the road and track with Cadillac’s roaring Blackwings, a Porsche 911 GTS and the rare BMW M2 CS.
content: For speed demons — or demons wedded to hellacious fossil-fuel power — the Cadillac CT5-V Blackwing checks off quite a list. A supercharged, 668-horsepower V-8. A top speed above 200 miles an hour. All-day track thrills that would leave any E.V. depleted and gasping, as demonstrated on my endorphin-rushing test laps at Virginia International Raceway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nathaniel Rich
title: All Screechers Great and Small: An Eco Fairy Tale
description: In Katherine Applegate’s “Willodeen,” an orphan girl in a land called Perchance learns that the fates of all of Earth’s creatures are intertwined.
content: WILLODEENBy Katherine ApplegateIllustrated by Charles Santoso
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere
title: F.D.A. Panel to Weigh Pfizer Shots for Children, Boosters for Moderna and Johnson & Johnson Recipients
description: The timing of the meetings later this month suggests that the agency plans to move quickly to decide both issues.
content: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday scheduled three days of public meetings with its panel of independent vaccine experts for later this month, as the agency prepares to make high-profile decisions on whether to authorize emergency use of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine for children ages 5 to 11 and booster shots for adult recipients of the Moderna and Johnson & Johnson vaccines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annabelle Williams
title: Teresa Miller, Law Professor and Prison Reformer, Is Dead at 59
description: Her work on prisoner’s rights at Attica aimed to convey the humanity of incarcerated people. She later worked on diversity efforts for SUNY.
content: When Teresa Miller, a professor at the University at Buffalo School of Law, showed her documentary film about the Attica Correctional Facility during a panel discussion at the Glimmerglass opera festival in 2014, it sparked an idea. Why not, she thought, bring an opera to the prison?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Rowland
title: New Southern Fiction By Percival Everett, Wiley Cash and Andrew Siegrist
description: Two mysteries and a story collection span the American South, from 1980s North Carolina to small-town Mississippi to Tennessee.
content: WHEN GHOSTS COME HOME By Wiley Cash290 pp. Morrow. $28.99.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Democrats, Divided
description: House Democrats delayed a vote on a major infrastructure bill, a sign of divisions within the party.
content: For more than a decade, congressional Democrats have been a notably unified and functional bunch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: California to Mandate Covid-19 Vaccines for All Students as Soon as Next Fall
description: Children from kindergarten to 12th grade in both public and private schools will be required to be inoculated against the coronavirus once the F.D.A. gives full approval.
content: SACRAMENTO — California’s governor on Friday issued the nation’s first statewide Covid-19 vaccine mandate for schoolchildren, saying they would be required as soon as next fall to be inoculated against the coronavirus to attend public and private schools in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Veronique Greenwood
title: This Parasite Turns Plants Into Zombies
description: It’s a never-ending cycle of “Night of the Living Dead-meets-Dracula” in the world of green and leafy things.
content: A mustard plant infected with a certain parasite grows strangely, its development warped by tiny invaders. Its leaves take on odd shapes, its stems form a bushy structure called a witches’ broom and it may grow flowers that do not produce seed. Most peculiarly of all, it lives longer than its uninfected brethren, in a state of perpetual adolescence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: Review: Love, Anger and Disgusting Toilets in Netflix’s ‘Maid’
description: Margaret Qualley plays a woman cleaning houses, and not always getting by, in an adaptation of a best-selling memoir.
content: “Maid” begins just after the last straw has been broken. Alex, a 25-year-old aspiring writer living north of Seattle, lies awake watching the man who just ended an argument with her by punching a hole in a wall. When she’s sure he’s asleep, she gathers their 2-year-old daughter, Maddy, and tiptoes out of the mobile home they share. She and Maddy are about to be homeless for the first time, but not the last.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: George Ferencz, Innovative Theater Director, Dies at 74
description: He directed works by Sam Shepard, Amiri Baraka and others at La MaMa and similar theaters known for experimentation.
content: George Ferencz, a director who was a fixture at theaters known for experimental work like La MaMa E.T.C. in Manhattan, died on Sept. 14 in Brooklyn. He was 74.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Marino
title: Steven Mnuchin Sells a Duplex on Park Avenue for $22.5 Million
description: The former secretary of the Treasury sold a duplex at 740 Park that had been in his family since the 1960s; and an apartment at the new Central Park Tower sold for $50 million.
content: Apartments at the ultraexpensive 220 Central Park South continue to appreciate in value in resales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk
title: He Sees Migrants as ‘Modern Slaves,’ and Has Devoted His Life to Helping Them
description: The Rev. Daniel Alliët, for whom Jesus was a “political revolutionary,” has made it his life’s mission to fight for the rights of undocumented migrants, to the chagrin of some other clergy members.
content: BRUSSELS — Wherever he goes in St. John the Baptist Church in Brussels, the Rev. Daniel Alliët finds himself quickly surrounded by a crowd, an unusual sight for a Roman Catholic church in largely secular Western Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Hitting The Road
description: Have you ever taken a road trip?
content: Scores of families took to the road this summer, taking their first “normal” vacations in ages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Selin Davis
title: TV and Movies Are Finally Celebrating Older Women
description: Until quite recently, anything past age 40 was considered ancient in Hollywood years. At long last, that’s starting to change.
content: — Carol Walker, the character played by Angela Bassett in the film “Otherhood”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane, Luke Broadwater and Jonathan Weisman
title: Biden puts the infrastructure bill on hold, saying Democrats need to unite on social spending.
description: The president went to Capitol Hill to try to unify Democrats around a bipartisan infrastructure bill and a broader social policy and climate package. But a deal did not appear to be in hand.
content: President Biden, facing an intraparty battle over his domestic agenda, put his own $1 trillion infrastructure bill on hold on Friday, telling Democrats that a vote on the popular measure must wait until Democrats pass his far more ambitious social policy and climate change package.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Fashion Mogul Agrees to Face Sex-Trafficking Charges in U.S.
description: Peter Nygard, a former fashion executive, will soon be extradited from Canada to the United States to face charges of sex trafficking and other crimes against women and teenage girls.
content: OTTAWA — Peter Nygard, the Canadian former fashion executive who was once given to boasting about his flamboyant lifestyle, waived a Canadian extradition hearing on Friday, a move that will bring him to the United States to face charges of sex trafficking and other crimes victimizing dozens of women and teenage girls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brandon Keim
title: The Marvelous Physics of Swarming Midges
description: There’s more in that cloud of bugs than meets the eye.
content: On early autumn afternoons across the temperate world, the midges are now gathering to swarm: clouds of tiny flies, wings lit by the sun like so many sparks, swirling in patterns too quick and complicated for the eye to follow but leaving a mental afterimage of order. Not a perfect order, but something more than chaos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Carnegie Hall Counts Down to Its Reopening
description: “The biggest variables — box office sales and venue rentals — are moving in a good direction,” says the director of the hall, which opens its season Oct. 6.
content: The pianos have been tuned. The crimson carpets have been cleaned. The crystal chandeliers have been dusted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angus Deaton
title: Two Authors View America From Above and Below, and Are Not Happy With What They See
description: Evan Osnos’s “Wildland” and Alec Ross’s “The Raging 2020s” take different paths to arrive at the same worrisome conclusion about the country’s future.
content: WILDLANDThe Making of America’s FuryBy Evan OsnosTHE RAGING 2020SCompanies, Countries, People — and the Fight for Our Future By Alec Ross
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Michael D. Shear
title: Progressives Flex Muscles on Biden Agenda, Adopting New Tactics
description: Their persistence forced Speaker Nancy Pelosi to delay a planned vote on the $1 trillion infrastructure bill. In the end, President Biden sided with their position.
content: WASHINGTON — Progressive Democrats in Congress, who have long promoted a bold, liberal agenda but often shied away from using hardball tactics to achieve it, did something unusual this week: They dug in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: North Korea Sends Confusing Signals: Dialogue or Tension?
description: This is not the first time the North has launched missiles or otherwise shown off its arsenal while suggesting that it was open to talks.
content: SEOUL — The signals are confusing. One day, North Korea is ​​raising hopes for dialogue with South Korea, and the next, it is firing missiles or showing off the latest weaponry in its nuclear arsenal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: Karen Dalton, a Musical Mystery That Doesn’t Need to Be Solved
description: A new documentary about the blues-folk singer, who died in 1993, works to make her known without unraveling all of her riddles.
content: The hauntingly soulful blues-folk singer Karen Dalton once described her dream concert: “She’d be in her living room with friends and playing music,” her friend and fellow musician Peter Stampfel recalls in the new documentary “Karen Dalton: In My Own Time.” “And then somehow the living room would be put on a huge stage, which would be surrounded by a massive audience who would be watching in rapt attention while she ignored them totally and just did whatever she wanted to do.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: Marie Antoinette’s Letters to Her Dear Swedish Count, Now Uncensored
description: Researchers used an X-ray technique to resurface the redacted text of letters exchanged between the queen and her dear friend Axel von Fersen.
content: The year was 1791, and while Marie Antoinette may not have had the favor of the people of France, she did have a pen pal. Her confidant, Axel von Fersen, was a Swedish count, and one of the French queen’s close friends.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Hass and Yvan Moreau
title: A 17th-Century Mansion Reimagined for the Future
description: A Parisian couple has created a home that pays tribute to designers of generations past while also envisioning what is to come.
content: THE 1960S CLOTHING designer Paco Rabanne was an unrepentant optimist. His chain-mail halter tops and micro-mini shifts strung together from metallic paillettes reflected the dream of a cleaner, cheerier planet — either ours or one far away. While today’s fashion futurism tends to be dystopian — somber cloaks, thigh-high black latex boots — the Basque-born Rabanne envisioned the world to come as groovy and expansive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefanos Chen
title: New Supertalls Test the Limits, as the City Consults an Aging Playbook
description: Only three of New York’s 25 tallest residential buildings — and none of the towers on Billionaires’ Row — have completed building safety tasks required by the city.
content: The skyscrapers of New York’s so-called Billionaires’ Row in Midtown Manhattan have something in common besides eye-watering prices: The city still considers them active construction sites, with a range of safety-related requirements that remain incomplete, sometimes years after occupancy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman and Lauren Leatherby
title: U.S. Coronavirus Death Toll Surpasses 700,000 Despite Wide Availability of Vaccines
description: The latest Covid-19 deaths were concentrated in the South, and included more younger people than before. Every age group under 55 saw its highest death toll of the pandemic this August.
content: The United States surpassed 700,000 deaths from the coronavirus on Friday, a milestone that few experts had anticipated months ago when vaccines became widely available to the American public.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alanis Thames
title: Career Night for Diana Taurasi Gets the Mercury Back on Track
description: The Phoenix Mercury tied their semifinal series against the Las Vegas Aces at one game apiece thanks to long-range sharpshooting from Taurasi.
content: Diana Taurasi grimaced on the court as her Phoenix Mercury teammates carefully pulled her to her feet late in the third quarter of Game 1 of the W.N.B.A. semifinals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Manchin, a key Democratic holdout, deepens the party’s impasse on Biden’s agenda.
description: Senator Joe Manchin III said Thursday night that $1.5 trillion in social spending — less than half what liberals have sought — “does exactly the necessary things we need to do.”
content: Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia, a key centrist holdout, panned the prospects of reaching a deal on Thursday on a framework for an expansive domestic and social policy package, holding firm to a $1.5 trillion price tag that liberals have said is too small.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Robbins
title: Merck Says It Has the First Antiviral Pill Found to Be Effective Against Covid
description: The drug maker will seek authorization for molnupiravir, the first drug of its kind for Covid. Experts said such pills could be a powerful tool against the virus.
content: The drug maker Merck said on Friday that its pill to treat Covid-19 was shown in a key clinical trial to halve the risk of hospitalization or death when given to high-risk people early in their infections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina
title: Trail Blazer
description: In Jewell Parker Rhodes’s “Paradise on Fire,” a young mapmaker in a wilderness program for Black city kids fights fire with fire.
content: PARADISE ON FIREBy Jewell Parker RhodesIllustrated by Serena Malyon
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis and Giulia Heyward
title: After Rape Accusations, Fraternities Face Protests and Growing Anger
description: At big universities with powerful fraternity cultures — like UMass, Northwestern, Nebraska and Iowa — many students are demanding an end to Greek life.
content: At the University of Nebraska-Lincoln, hundreds of students protested outside a fraternity house in August after a student reported a sexual assault by one of its members to the police.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: 700,000 deaths and Covid social anxiety
content: The U.S. is about to reach 700,000 deaths from Covid-19. This latest milestone is different because the last 100,000 people to die passed away months after vaccines were available to American adults.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Jonathan Martin
title: Sinema, a holdout on the social spending bill, returns to Arizona for a doctor’s visit and a scheduled fund-raiser.
description: In contrast, the other holdout to support President Biden’s sweeping social spending bill, Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia, is remaining in Washington this weekend.
content: With Democrats pleading for a deal on a hard-fought social safety net bill, one of the key holdouts, Senator Kyrsten Sinema of Arizona, left Washington on Friday. The reason, her spokesman said, was a medical appointment for a foot injury.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: When the Doctor’s Notes Hurt Your Feelings
description: Are you a “poor historian,” “well nourished” or in need of a “time out”? As patients gain access to their own medical records, the notes left by doctors can sting.
content: Have you ever been insulted by your own medical records?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Raphael Minder
title: In Portugal, There Is Virtually No One Left to Vaccinate
description: Portugal is among the most highly vaccinated countries in the world. Vice Adm. Henrique Gouveia e Melo, who led the campaign, said there was a key to his success: Keep politics out of it.
content: Portugal’s health care system was on the verge of collapse. Hospitals in the capital, Lisbon, were overflowing and the authorities were asking people to treat themselves at home. In the last week of January, nearly 2,000 people died as the virus spread.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas May
title: Enescu, an Underplayed Composer, Is Still a Star in Romania
description: The pandemic could not derail the sprawling George Enescu International Festival in Bucharest.
content: BUCHAREST, Romania — Romania has a long record of defying the catastrophes history has served up, so it certainly would not allow the pandemic to derail the George Enescu International Festival, devoted to its premier musical native son, which ended on Sunday. At stake was not only the 25th edition of this country’s largest cultural event, but also the renewal of a global artistic exchange that this still-marginalized part of Europe considers essential to its development.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. Mina and Steven Phillips
title: Rapid Tests Are the Answer to Living With Covid-19
description: Americans need both vaccines and universal access to rapid tests to get back to more normalcy.
content: In Germany, you can buy a rapid Covid-19 test at the grocery store for one euro (a little more than a dollar). In Britain, any household can obtain a pack of seven rapid tests every day for free. In Singapore, you can get a free rapid test from a vending machine. Families in Israel receive at-home rapid tests for their children to use before school. Rapid testing is commonplace in many parts of the world because policymakers recognized early on that the tests could blunt the pandemic by stopping chains of transmission. By letting people know they are infectious, rapid tests are useful even in areas with high vaccination rates and can allow for a safer return to in-person activity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Kennedy
title: ‘Britney vs Spears’ Review: When the Intervention Is the Problem
description: A Netflix documentary directed by Erin Lee Carr offers a timely if vexing primer on the pop star’s legal battle, which may finally be coming to an end.
content: If the makers of “Britney vs Spears” could add one more update to the end of the documentary’s already lengthy text crawl of developments following the film’s completion, they’d have fresh material. On Wednesday, a judge agreed to the suspension of the pop star’s father, James P. Spears, as her conservator.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Samuel Earle
title: Britain Is Heading Into a Nightmarish Winter
description: A sudden convergence of crises  has cast the country’s future in darkness.
content: LONDON — Long lines outside gas stations. Panicked drivers fighting one another as the pumps run dry. Soldiers deployed to distribute fuel across the country. And in the background, the pandemic stretching on, food rotting in fields and families sinking into poverty. This is Britain in 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Cherish the Feel-Good Stories. They Won’t Last.
description: Enjoy the underdogs now, because money will restore Europe’s usual order soon enough.
content: By Wednesday night, the humiliation was complete. In the space of 24 hours, the two teams that had for so long regarded themselves as the pinnacle of modern soccer — the greatest clubs in the world, the inevitable destinations of the game’s best and brightest, the rightful possessors of its biggest trophies — had been humbled, one after the other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley
title: A Princess Is Set to Be Wed. But It’s No Fairy Tale.
description: Princess Mako of Japan will forgo the trappings of royal nuptials when she marries her college boyfriend, a commoner, after a long and arduous engagement.
content: TOKYO — Anyone who dreams of being a princess should probably have a chat with Princess Mako of Japan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Jeff Bezos’ Rocket Company Accused of Toxic Culture and Safety Issues
description: Blue Origin launched the Amazon founder to the edge of space in July and has another flight planned in October, but the company has experienced other setbacks this year.
content: Former and current employees at Blue Origin, the rocket company started by Jeff Bezos, the founder of Amazon and one of the richest people in the world, say the company is rife with sexism, intolerant of employees who dare to contradict their bosses and lax on safety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: How African Countries Can Overcome the ‘Resource Curse’
description: Eight of the 15 countries with the least diversified exports are in Africa.
content: Africa is home to eight of the world’s 15 least-diversified economies, according to an International Monetary Fund analysis of the export composition of countries as of 2014. The African eight are Algeria, Angola, Equatorial Guinea, Gabon, Libya and Nigeria (oil), Botswana (diamonds) and Eritrea (livestock).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: They Were Promised a Chance at Parole in 10 Years. It’s Been 50.
description: Relief could be imminent for several of Louisiana’s longest-serving inmates, whose cases have drawn renewed attention generations after the state changed their parole eligibility requirements.
content: For dozens of Louisiana’s oldest and longest-serving inmates, the choice could not have been more stark: Risk getting sent to the electric chair for rape or murder, or sign a plea agreement that carried a life sentence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Is the Coronavirus Getting Better at Airborne Transmission?
description: The Alpha variant traveled more efficiently in small droplets, two new studies found. The Delta variant may have continued this evolution.
content: Newer variants of the coronavirus like Alpha and Delta are highly contagious, infecting far more people than the original virus. Two new studies offer a possible explanation: The virus is evolving to spread more efficiently through air.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The World Wants Greenland’s Minerals, but Greenlanders Are Wary
description: The island has rare elements needed for electric cars and wind turbines. But protesters are blocking one project, signaling that mining companies must tread carefully.
content: NARSAQ, Greenland — This huge, remote and barely habited island is known for frozen landscapes, remote fjords and glaciers that heave giant sheets of ice into the sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Israel Meléndez Ayala, Alicia Kennedy and Damon Winter
title: How the U.S. Dictates What Puerto Rico Eats
description: Outdated laws prevent local farmers from competing effectively with mainland products.
content: SAN JUAN, P.R. — In 1953, the Visitors Bureau of the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico released a promotional film to entice visitors called “Fiesta Island.” The island and its people are presented as exotic oddities, reflecting the colonialist attitudes of the era, and one gets the impression that Puerto Ricans desire nothing more than to serve American tourists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner and Sabrina Tavernise
title: Federal Judge Hears Arguments Over Texas Abortion Law
description: The Justice Department said the law was intended to “violate the Constitution,” and asked for it to be suspended while the courts determine if it is legal.
content: WASHINGTON — A federal judge heard arguments on Friday from the State of Texas and the federal government on whether a Texas law that bans nearly all abortions in the state should be suspended while the courts decide if it is legal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: You Can Get Your Credit Score, but You May Have to Pay for It
description: A new Consumer Reports analysis of five credit apps also found that the scores might differ from the ones a lender would use.
content: Despite the popularity of mobile apps promising easy access to credit information, obtaining free, bona fide credit scores remains a challenge for consumers, according to a new analysis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: How Does Social Media Affect Your Mental Health?
description: Facebook has delayed the development of an Instagram app for children amid questions about its harmful effects on young people’s mental health. Does social media have an impact on your well-being?
content: What is your relationship with social media like? Which platforms do you spend the most time on? Which do you stay away from? How often do you log on?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Orr
title: ‘Ted Lasso’ Recap, Season 2, Episode 11: Nate the Not-So-Great
description: Also: Sam gets a remarkable offer. And are Keeley and Roy OK?
content: And when you least expect it, “Ted Lasso” has something to say about … soccer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cora Engelbrecht and Jasmina Nielsen
title: In the Name of Art, an Artist Pockets $83,000 and Creates Nothing
description: The artist delivered two blank canvases titled ‘Take the Money and Run’ to a Danish museum. He was commissioned to produce a commentary on work in the modern world.
content: ​The title of the artwork was a clue to the artist’s intentions — “Take the Money and Run.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Krauss
title: New in Paperback: ‘Conditional Citizens’ and ‘The Silence’
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
content: THE SWORD AND THE SHIELD: The Revolutionary Lives of Malcolm X and Martin Luther King Jr., by Peniel E. Joseph. (Basic, 400 pp., $18.99.) Arguing for a “new interpretation” of these two iconic civil rights leaders — in what our reviewer, Annette Gordon-Reed, called an “immensely valuable” book — Joseph suggests that while they may have been polar opposites at the start, they gradually moved toward each other before their assassinations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Why does Washington do everything at the last minute? It’s complicated.
description: The proliferation of dramatic, last-second congressional deals has increased dramatically in the hyperpartisan environment of the past quarter-century.
content: The wrenching intraparty battle taking place among Democrats on Capitol Hill is a unique, perhaps historical, reckoning — but it is also the most Groundhog Day of Washington crises: a frenzy of last-second action preceded by epic procrastination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Rothman and Shaina Feinberg
title: Untoxicating Drinks for Sober October
description: “There’s a whole thing of just having something in your hand when you’re in a social setting.” The owner of a nonalcoholic beverage shop on ditching booze.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi
title: Europe’s Social Democrats Show Signs of Life, but France Poses a Roadblock
description: Center-left parties have won a string of victories, capped by Olaf Scholz’s win in Germany. Yet, France’s struggling Socialists threaten hopes for a broader social democratic revival.
content: PARIS — For France’s venerable Socialist Party, languishing at 4 percent support ahead of next year’s presidential elections, news of a surprise win last Sunday by its center-left counterpart in Germany offered a glimmer of hope.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tressie McMillan Cottom
title: Why Everyone Is Always Giving Unsolicited Advice
description: And why, even though I hate it, small talk is so important.
content: A friend recently wondered aloud whether she has a sign around her neck, invisible to her, that solicits strangers for advice. She enjoyed a respite from unsolicited feedback when we were at our most vigilant about social distancing during the Covid-19 pandemic, but with a shift back toward normalcy, the fragile détente seems to have been called off. During a recent routine trip to her favorite cafe, no fewer than four people offered her advice on crossing the street, choosing a pastry and reading material. She takes it in stride but she knew I would be a sympathetic ear: I am on record as being very cautious about giving advice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Clare Toeniskoetter, Kaitlin Roberts, Jessica Cheung, Daniel Guillemette, Lisa Chow, Marion Lozano, Elisheba Ittoop and Chris Wood
title: ‘They Don’t Understand That We’re Real People’
description: The new Texas abortion law — the country’s most restrictive — is already having an impact in the state and elsewhere.
content: This episode contains strong language.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Recaps This Year’s Congressional Baseball Game
description: “It was just baseball, no politics, until the Republican catcher went nuts about having to wear a mask,” Jimmy Fallon said on Thursday night.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: A Year in the Life: Who Gets a Master’s Degree in the Beatles?
description: In Liverpool, England, a postgraduate program aims to turn Beatles fans into serious students of the band’s legacy.
content: LIVERPOOL, England — On Wednesday morning, as a new semester began, students eagerly headed into the University of Liverpool’s lecture theaters to begin courses in archaeology, languages and international relations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Irwin
title: Nobody Really Knows How the Economy Works. A Fed Paper Is the Latest Sign.
description: Many experts are rethinking longstanding core ideas, including the importance of inflation expectations.
content: It has long been a central tenet of mainstream economic theory that public fears of inflation tend to be self-fulfilling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Burke
title: A Dance Show on a Cruise Ship? It’s Not What You Think.
description: These artists doubted Virgin Voyages would want what they had to offer. But their show, part revue, part night out at a club, is about to set sail.
content: On a late-summer night, three choreographers greeted friends at the New York opening of their latest show, exchanging hugs and chatting through masks over the blare of pop music. Neon projections in the theater, a nightclub-like space called the Red Room, exclaimed “Welcome to the Show!!” Cocktail servers wove efficiently through the crowd with trays of drinks, as nimble as the dancers who would soon take the stage.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Editors’ Note: Oct. 1, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Oct. 1, 2021.
content: An article on Tuesday about increasing fears among women that the Taliban will restrict their access to education included several comments from an individual claiming to be Mohammad Ashraf Ghairat, the newly appointed chancellor of Kabul University, saying that women would not be allowed to go to work or attend classes at the college. The comments included those posted to a Twitter account in Mr. Ghairat’s name. Multiple calls to the chancellor’s office and his top aide for confirmation were turned away, with the aide saying that the chancellor would not speak to the media, and referring questions to a senior Taliban spokesman, who did not deny the account’s claims. After publication of the article, the authenticity of the account was cast into doubt, and The Times has been unable to reach the university’s chancellor to confirm his position on school policies. (The digital version of the article and its accompanying headline have been updated to reflect doubts about the social media posts.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judy Mandell
title: Taking the Slow Route to the Altar
description: Amy Ogbonna and Samuel Oiwoh matched on Tinder in 2014 but ignored the connection. Soon after, they ran into each other — and gradually made their way to marriage.
content: Amy Ogbonna and Samuel Oiwoh both swiped right on the dating app Tinder in December 2014, but neither of them messaged the other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charanna Alexander
title: Love Letter: OkCupid Saved My Marriage
description: And: He passed her woke test.
content: Gayle Brandeis, the writer of this week’s Modern Love essay, wasn’t sure if her marriage could rebound from her obsession with another man. However, a glimmer of hope arrived in the form of an unexpected 98 percent match on a dating app. That match was with her husband, and from there they were able to rebuild.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Progressive Democrats celebrate delaying the vote on the infrastructure bill.
description: The Democrats’ most liberal wing continues to push for action on a far larger social spending bill before they agree to rally behind the infrastructure legislation.
content: Progressive activists have long lamented what they see as liberal lawmakers’ tendency to back down in the middle of tough negotiations with Democratic leaders. Not so last night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Jackson and Soraya Shockley
title: A Third Pandemic School Year
description: We called our sources in Odessa, Texas, to check in.
content: Welcome to the weekend. Britney Spears, abortion, Haitian refugees: We covered a lot of ground on the show this week. Was there an episode that stood out to you — or one you’d like us to follow up on? Let us know. We always love to hear from you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Anna Schaverien
title: Chopra in Charge
description: Rohit Chopra’s confirmation as the next director of the C.F.P.B. is part of President Biden’s push to rein in corporate power.
content: After months in limbo, Rohit Chopra was narrowly confirmed by the Senate yesterday as the next director of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau in a 50-to-48 party-line vote. Republicans had resisted Chopra’s confirmation, with the Senate Banking Committee’s ranking member, Patrick Toomey of Pennsylvania, saying he would use the bureau’s powers to pursue an “aggressively anti-business agenda.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: I Can’t Stop Making This Dish
description: Egg rice, complete with buttery soy sauce drippings, makes for satisfying eating.
content: We have a new favorite recipe in the rotation at our house: Eric Kim’s version of gyeran bap, a dish he paid homage to in his column in The New York Times Magazine a few weeks ago. Several cultures have a dish like this, a soul-satisfying combination of fried egg and rice, topped as you like. I’ve made variations on egg rice many times, but I especially love Eric’s method of allowing the butter to brown, and his addition of soy sauce to the pan (which makes for, as he describes them, “buttery soy sauce drippings”). We eat this for lunch, though it’s just as good for breakfast, dinner or snacking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Wonking Out: Biden Should Ignore the Debt Limit and Mint a $1 Trillion Coin
description: Now is the time for some courageous gimmickry.
content: It’s hard to believe now, but before Donald Trump became the G.O.P.’s presidential nominee in 2016, Senator Marco Rubio of Florida was widely seen as a champion of the “reformicons” — conservatives who wanted the Republican Party to become more moderate and flexible, to move beyond its obsessive focus on cutting taxes for the rich and slashing benefits for the poor. Since then, however, Rubio has become a pathetic figure — not just a Trump toady, but someone who routinely tweets out stuff like this: “The $3.5 trillion Biden plan isn’t socialism, it’s Marxism.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: North Korea Continues a Barrage of Missile Tests
description: The North said it tested a new antiaircraft missile, the second missile test this week and the seventh this year, indicating that it is ramping up its weapons development.
content: SEOUL — North Korea said on Friday that it had test-launched a newly developed antiaircraft missile, carrying out the latest in a flurry of weapons tests in recent weeks even as it has declared an openness to dialogue with the South.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: At the Mets’ Home Finale, Change Was in the Air
description: New leaders will be ushered in this off-season. But even in a year marred by a monumental collapse, a core group of stars offers something not every team has: hope.
content: The Mets played their last home game of the season on Thursday in the final hours of September. It was dark at game time, and the flags flapped atop Citi Field in the cool breeze. Most of the players did not wear long sleeves, but most of the fans bundled up. Summer is over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosalie R. Radomsky
title: A Scripted Ceremony Takes Center Stage
description: Cary Gitter, a playwright, and Meghan VanArsdalen, an actor, were married at the Gem Theater in Detroit. He scripted the ceremony.
content: Cary Gitter texted his friend Sylvia Khoury out of the blue in September 2017 to ask about her friend Meghan VanArsdalen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Klonick
title: Clearly, Facebook Is Very Flawed. What Will We Do About It?
description: A  damning expose depicts a company with all the information it needs to fix the egregious oversights and mistakes of the past.
content: Two weeks ago, The Wall Street Journal published “The Facebook Files,” a damning series based on a cache of leaked internal documents that revealed how much the company knew about the harms it was causing and how little it did to stop it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Emily Cochrane
title: House Delays Vote on Infrastructure Bill as Democrats Feud
description: A liberal revolt left Democrats short of votes, but leaders insisted they would bring up the measure again on Friday, giving them more time to reach a deal on a separate climate and safety net bill.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s trillion-dollar bipartisan infrastructure plan suffered a significant setback late Thursday night when House Democratic leaders, short of support amid a liberal revolt, put off a planned vote on a crucial plank of their domestic agenda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liana Finck
title: We All Have a Book In Us. Or Do We?
description: Liana Finck illustrates what it looks like when our best ideas are let loose upon the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: He Speaks Theater’s Language (and Many Others, Too)
description: Tiago Rodrigues, the newly appointed director of the Avignon Festival, will make his BAM debut, in English, with a work he has also performed in French, Greek, Portuguese, Russian and Spanish.
content: LISBON — Theater knows no language barriers for the Portuguese actor and director Tiago Rodrigues. At the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where he will make his house debut on Oct. 12, he will perform “By Heart,” a solo show with audience participation, in English.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Get the Look: Distorted Reality Version
description: In a fog of mystery, disco and breastplates at Rick Owens, Chloé, Raf Simons and Loewe.
content: PARIS — The thick, white fog rolled across the plaza of the Palais de Tokyo on a gorgeous sunny day like a scrim of cotton wadding, fuzzing the view, making it hard to see what was coming next. It was the Rick Owens show, but the clouding of reality seemed awfully familiar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: Ed or Julia? Freedom or Valor? Army Base Names Are Changing. But to What?
description: Congress mandated renaming military bases that commemorate Confederate leaders. The communities around them are now weighing in.
content: FAYETTEVILLE, N.C. — Braxton Bragg was an ill-tempered, largely failed Confederate general from a slave-owning family whose history has been omitted from the training curriculum for troops on the installation that bears his name. But many service members and residents of the adjacent town have learned all about him in recent months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Woo
title: Key takeaways from the fourth week of the Elizabeth Holmes trial.

author: By Lindsay Talbot

description: Bottega Veneta has always relied on its braiding pattern, rather than logos, for brand recognition. Its new bag updates the technique with a novel weave.
content: Bottega Veneta began in 1966 as a leather-goods company based in the Italian town of Vicenza, focused on quiet sophistication and meticulous craftsmanship. Nearly a decade later, the brand debuted a collection of handbags, made by artisans in the Veneto region, using a centuries-old weaving method called intrecciato, meaning “intertwined.” That style — which involves interlocking long, fettuccine-thin strips of leather into a braided pattern that resembles a lattice pie crust — quickly became the leitmotif of the house, known for refraining from logos altogether. In the ’80s, Lauren Hutton carried one of its intrecciato clutches in “American Gigolo” (1980), and Andy Warhol, who often turned to Bottega for his Christmas shopping, was photographed holding up a braided loafer in a department store. (The artist was such a fan of the brand that he produced a short film for the company in 1985.) To teach future artisans the intrecciato method, which takes up to three years of training to master, Bottega partnered with the Scuola d’Arte e Mestieri in Vicenza, an institution devoted to handmaking crafts such as leather goods.
